content:
While discussing with a friend we realized that the Delta generated spaces are actually generated by paths.
I find this very surprising.
https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/Delta-generated+topological+space
I was going to add the proof to this page but because of the current state of the nlab I don't think it's editable so i'm posting it here
Let Π\PiΠ be the functor Top→Top\mathbf{Top}\to\mathbf{Top}Top→Top which associates to each space XXX the finest topology such that every path in XXX lifts to a path in Π(X)\Pi(X)Π(X).
Prop - Suppose XXX is first countable and locally path-connected. Then Π(X)\Pi(X)Π(X) is homeomorphic to XXX.

Let xxx be a point in XXX. We know already that the map Π(X)→X\Pi(X)\to XΠ(X)→X is continuous. Let WWW be a neighborhood of xxx in the Π(X)\Pi(X)Π(X) topology; we will show that WWW is a neighborhood of xxx in the original topology.

Without loss of generality we can choose a small path connected open neighborhood of xxx and restrict to considering this subspace. Therefore wlog suppose XXX is path connected.

First-countable spaces are, in particular, sequential, so it suffices to show that every sequence {xn}\{ x_n \}{xn​} approaching xxx in the original topology is eventually in WWW. Introduce such a sequence. Let {Uk} \{U_k\}{Uk​} be a countable neighborhood basis of xxx; without loss of generality suppose the sequence is descending. Let {Vk}\{V_k\}{Vk​} be a sequence of path-connected open neighborhoods of xxx with Vk⊂UkV_k\subset U_kVk​⊂Uk​.

Without loss of generality assume that all the xnx_nxn​ live in V0V_0V0​, discarding from the sequence the finitely many that do not.

Define a function T:N→NT : \mathbb{N}\to\mathbb{N}T:N→N, where we let T(k)T(k)T(k) be the greatest natural number such that xi∈VT(k)x_i \in V_{T(k)}xi​∈VT(k)​ for all i≥ki \geq ki≥k (or kkk if there is no upper bound.) T(k)T(k)T(k) is monotonically increasing and grows to infinity.

For each natural number kkk choose a path σk\sigma_kσk​ from xkx_kxk​ to xk+1x_{k+1}xk+1​ in VT(k)V_{T(k)}VT(k)​. Assemble these sequences into a single path σ:I→X\sigma: I\to Xσ:I→X which is defined by σk\sigma_kσk​ on the interval [1−2−k,1−2−(k+1)][1 - 2^{-k}, 1- 2^{-(k+1)}][1−2−k,1−2−(k+1)], and define σ(1)=x\sigma(1) = xσ(1)=x. It is obvious that σ\sigmaσ is continuous at all points less than 111. To prove it is continuous at 111, it suffices to prove that each σ−1(Un)\sigma^{-1}(U_n)σ−1(Un​) is a neighborhood of 111. This holds because eventually all the segments that compose the path σ\sigmaσ lie in VkV_kVk​ for some k>nk> nk>n, and Vk⊂UnV_k \subset U_nVk​⊂Un​ for $k > n$$.

Thus σ\sigmaσ is continuous. Since WWW is a neighborhood in the Π(X)\Pi(X)Π(X) topology, there exists some ϵ\epsilonϵ such that σ((1−ϵ,1])⊂W\sigma( (1-\epsilon, 1])\subset Wσ((1−ϵ,1])⊂W. But by the construction of σ\sigmaσ this means that all but finitely many points xnx_nxn​ are in WWW, and since XXX is sequential, WWW is a neighborhood of xxx in XXX. This concludes the proof.

Applying this proposition, simplices are obviously first countable and locally path connected, thus Π(Δn)≅Δn\Pi(\Delta^n)\cong \Delta^nΠ(Δn)≅Δn for all nnn.

It follows that if f:Δn→Xf : \Delta^n\to Xf:Δn→X is continuous, then Π(f):Π(Δn)→Π(X)\Pi(f) : \Pi(\Delta^n) \to \Pi(X)Π(f):Π(Δn)→Π(X) can be composed with this homeomorphism to give a continuous map Δn≅Π(Δn)→Π(X)\Delta^n\cong \Pi(\Delta^n)\to \Pi(X)Δn≅Π(Δn)→Π(X). So every singular nnn-simplex factors through the Π\PiΠ-topology, i.e. Π\PiΠ is right adjoint to the forgetful functor from Δ\DeltaΔ generated spaces to all spaces.
It runs badly counter to my intuition. Somehow one-dimensional paths should not be able to access or reconstruct higher dimensional data... but I think the proof is correct, anyway.

The nLab is editable! That got sorted a little while back, the migration to the new software that was holding up being able to edit was canned. Please also pop in an edit summary if and when you do put in in there, and check the nForum for subsequent discussion

Isn't the space Π(X)\Pi(X)Π(X) the same underlying set as XXX plus the final topology coming from all continuous functions I→XI\to XI→X? That is, we can write Π(X)\Pi(X)Π(X) as a quotient ∐XII↠Π(X)\coprod_{X^I} I \twoheadrightarrow \Pi(X)∐XI​I↠Π(X). I'm wondering if there is anything that could be done with this quotient map, together with the one exhibiting XXX itself as a quotient of a coproduct of topological simplices (of all dimensions), which give a commuting square. Maybe that's too formal.

I like your idea, though. It's reminiscent of [[Boman's theorem]], which is very close to being (if not the same as) the analogous statement in the category of smooth manifolds, using R\mathbb{R}R instead of [0,1][0,1][0,1].

David Michael Roberts said:

Isn't the space Π(X)\Pi(X)Π(X) the same underlying set as XXX plus the final topology coming from all continuous functions I→XI\to XI→X? That is, we can write Π(X)\Pi(X)Π(X) as a quotient ∐XII↠Π(X)\coprod_{X^I} I \twoheadrightarrow \Pi(X)∐XI​I↠Π(X). I'm wondering if there is anything that could be done with this quotient map, together with the one exhibiting XXX itself as a quotient of a coproduct of topological simplices (of all dimensions), which give a commuting square. Maybe that's too formal.

Yes, that's the space I'm talking about.

Hmmm. For comparison, is it surprising that the category of sequential spaces is generated by the "free convergent sequence"? I think this is a similar phenomenon. Your argument seems to show that, for a first-countable locally path connected space, knowing about the paths also tells you about the convergent sequences, so such spaces are also "path-generated". Since the standard simplices are first-countable locally path connected, this implies Δ-spaces are "path-generated".
There are surjective continuous maps Δ1→Δn\Delta^1 \to \Delta^nΔ1→Δn for any nnn (space-filling curves), which give an "explicit" description of Δn\Delta^nΔn as a quotient of Δ1\Delta^1Δ1.
I was wondering about that whether the existence of space filling curves has anything to do with it, but I don't see how...
Clark Barwick always refers to Δ\DeltaΔ-generated spaces as "numerically-generated spaces", precisely because they are generated by R\mathbb{R}R.
